Bayesian sum of single-effect (susie) linear regression of Y on X

Bayesian sum of single-effect (susie) linear regression of Y on X

susie(X, Y, L = 10, scaled_prior_variance = 0.2,
  residual_variance = NULL, prior_weights = NULL, null_weight = NULL,
  standardize = TRUE, intercept = TRUE,
  estimate_residual_variance = TRUE, estimate_prior_variance = FALSE,
  s_init = NULL, coverage = 0.95, min_abs_corr = 0.5,
  compute_univariate_zscore = FALSE, max_iter = 100, tol = 0.001,
  verbose = FALSE, track_fit = FALSE)

Arguments

X

an n by p matrix of covariates
Y

an n vector
L

maximum number of non-zero effects
scaled_prior_variance

the scaled prior variance (vector of length L, or scalar. In latter case gets repeated L times). The prior variance on each non-zero element of b is set to be var(Y)*scaled_prior_variance.
residual_variance

the residual variance (defaults to variance of Y)
prior_weights

a p vector of prior probability that each element is non-zero
null_weight

probability of no effect, for each single effect model
standardize

logical flag (default=TRUE) for whether to standardize columns of X to unit variance prior to fitting. Note that `scaled_prior_variance` specifies the prior on the coefficients of X *after* standardization (if performed). If you do not standardize you may need to think more carefully about specifying `scaled_prior_variance`. Whatever the value of standardize, the coefficients (returned from `coef`) are for X on the original input scale. Any column of X that has zero variance is not standardized, but left as is.
intercept

Should intercept be fitted (default=TRUE) or set to zero (FALSE). The latter is generally not recommended.
estimate_residual_variance

indicates whether to estimate residual variance
estimate_prior_variance

indicates whether to estimate prior (currently not recommended as not fully tested and assessed)
s_init

a previous susie fit with which to initialize
coverage

coverage of confident sets. Default to 0.95 for 95% confidence interval.
min_abs_corr

minimum of absolute value of correlation allowed in a confidence set. Default set to 0.5 to correspond to squared correlation of 0.25, a commonly used threshold for genotype data in genetics studies.
compute_univariate_zscore

if true, outputs z-score from per variable univariate regression
max_iter

maximum number of iterations to perform
tol

convergence tolerance
verbose

if true outputs some progress messages
track_fit

add an attribute trace to output that saves current values of all iterations

Value

a susie fit, which is a list with some or all of the following elements

alpha

an L by p matrix of posterior inclusion probabilites

mu

an L by p matrix of posterior means (conditional on inclusion)

mu2

an L by p matrix of posterior second moments (conditional on inclusion)

Xr

an n vector of fitted values, equal to X times colSums(alpha*mu))

sigma2

residual variance

V

prior variance

elbo

a vector of values of elbo achieved (objective function)

sets

a list of `cs`, `purity` and selected `cs_index`

pip

a vector of posterior inclusion probability

z

a vector of univariate z-scores

Details

Performs sum of single-effect (susie) linear regression of Y on X. That is, this function fits the regression model Y= sum_l Xb_l + e, where elements of e are iid N(0,residual_variance) and the sum_l b_l is a p vector of effects to be estimated. The assumption is that each b_l has exactly one non-zero element, with all elements equally likely to be non-zero. The prior on the non-zero element is N(0,var=var(Y)*scaled_prior_variance).

Examples

set.seed(1)
n = 1000
p = 1000
beta = rep(0,p)
beta[1:4] = 1
X = matrix(rnorm(n*p),nrow=n,ncol=p)
y = X %*% beta + rnorm(n)
res =susie(X,y,L=10)
coef(res)
